Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM)
DC recognizes the importance of STEM as part of a well-rounded educational experience. STEM skills and knowledge are not only valuable components to a solid academic program, but also core fundamentals for life experience. STEM skills and knowledge help students develop logic, problem-solving, and critical thinking skills that can be used in every discipline and that enable them to compete in the continually growing high-tech job sector. As such, DC strives to improve STEM opportunities for all its students and has established the following statewide goals for STEM:
Goal 1: To prepare all students in DC to graduate high school with a college- and career-ready mastery of math, science, engineering and technology
Goal 2: To increase the number of DC students who major in STEM fields in college and enter STEM careers

title: Module 3: Quantity and Operations
text:
Module Overview
This module explores the mathematical concepts focusing on quantity and operations within the context of elementary mathematics. The module covers the historical development of arithmetic operations, introduces the Concrete-Representational-Abstract (CRA) approach to teaching mathematics, delves into the properties of basic arithmetic operations, and examines the relationships between different operations. By the end of this module, you will have a comprehensive understanding of quantity and operations to effectively deal with various mathematical representations.

title: Module 3: Quantity and Operations
text:
Concrete-Representational-Abstract (CRA)
The Concrete-Representational-Abstract (CRA) process is an instructional approach in mathematics that helps students develop a deeper understanding of mathematical concepts by progressing through three stages:

Concrete Stage:


Students use physical, hands-on objects to model mathematical concepts
Examples include base-10 blocks, counters, fraction bars, or algebra tiles
This stage allows students to manipulate tangible objects to solve problems




Image from CRA methods by the Mathematics Initiative at www.pattan.net



Representational (or Pictorial) Stage:


Students transition to using visual representations of the concrete objects
This may involve drawings, diagrams, or other pictorial models
Examples include number lines, bar models, or sketches of manipulatives




Image from CRA methods by the Mathematics Initiative at www.pattan.net



Abstract Stage:


Students work with abstract symbols and notation
This includes numbers, variables, and mathematical symbols (+, -, x, ÷)
Students apply their understanding to solve problems using standard algorithms




Image from CRA methods by the Mathematics Initiative at www.pattan.net


The CRA approach deepens mathematical understanding and help students internalize abstract concepts by first grounding them in concrete experiences.

title: Module 3: Quantity and Operations
text:
Teaching Exponents
Pattern Blocks
Pattern blocks can be used to visually demonstrate exponents. For example:

Use one triangle to represent \(1 \times 1\)
Four triangles together represent \(2 \times 2\)
Nine triangles together represent \(3 \times 3\)


Draw the pattern for \(4 \times 4\) and \(5 \times 5\).
These patterns helps students visualize the quantity of exponents but we want to also show them representations of exponents as repeated multiplication; we can use base-ten blocks to extend their understanding.
Base Ten Blocks
Base ten blocks work well for teaching powers of 10:

A unit cube represents \(10^0 = (1)\)
A rod represents \(10^1 = 10 = (10)\)
A flat represents \(10^2 = 10 x 10 = (100)\)
A large cube represents \(10^3 = 10 x 10 x 10 = (1000)\)

Grid Paper
Grid paper allows students to draw squares and rectangles to represent exponents:

A \(2 x 2\) square represents \(2^2\)
A \(3 x 3\) square represents \(3^2\)
A \(2 x 2 x 2\) cube represents \(2^3\)


Draw the figures representing \(3^3\) and \(4^2\).

title: Module 3: Quantity and Operations
text:
Teaching Roots
Algebra Tiles
Algebra tiles are also good for teaching square roots:

Use the square tiles to build perfect square numbers (1, 4, 9, 16, etc.)
The side length of the square represents the square root

For example, a \(3x3\) square of tiles has an area of \(9\), so the square root of \(9\) is \(3\).
Grid Paper
Grid paper can be used to estimate non-perfect square roots:

Draw a square with the given area (e.g. 17)
Count the side length to estimate the square root
Refine by adding partial squares

This provides a visual model for estimating irrational square roots.

Number Lines
Use a number line to place square roots between perfect squares:

Mark perfect squares (1, 4, 9, 16, 25, etc.)
Estimate locations of other square roots between them

This helps students understand square roots as numbers between integers.
We can use manipulatives to build conceptual understanding before moving to procedures. Allow students to explore and discover patterns through hands-on activities. Gradually connect the concrete models to symbolic notation as students gain understanding.

Historical STEM Figures
This module closes with the identification of a historical figure in STEM.

Objective
Research a historical STEM figure and create engaging content to showcase their contributions. The historical figure should showcase the growing diversity of a host of identities, cultures, and backgrounds represented in STEM.


Procedures

Museum visit (75 minutes): Smithsonian Museum exhibit. Please take notes on interesting STEM figures and exhibits.
Figure selection and background research: Choose a historical STEM figure based on museum inspiration. Conduct additional research using archival resources and online databases.
Content creation: Students create content about their chosen figure in one of the following formats: Detailed video presentation (e.g., Tiktoc), Visual infographic (e.g., Canva), Interactive digital timeline, Podcast-like episode, Digital exhibit
Peer review: Students your work with classmates for feedback. Make final adjustments based on peer feedback.
Presentation (5 minutes): Develop a 5-minute presentation in the style that you would present it to your student. Present finished content to the class as if you were in front of your future students.

title: Module 5: Lesson planning and assessment
text: This module focuses on developing engaging and effective mathematics lessons for elementary students. We’ll explore creative teaching methods, organization of standards and activities, and strategies for improving assessments, particularly in the context of high-stakes testing.

title: Module 5: Lesson planning and assessment
text:
Creative Methods in Mathematics Teaching






Engaging students in mathematics requires innovative approaches that make abstract concepts tangible and exciting.




Examples of Creative Teaching Methods:

Math Storytelling: Integrate mathematical concepts into narratives.

Example: “The Great Shape Adventure” - a story where geometric shapes are characters solving problems.

Gamification: Turn math lessons into games.

Example: “Fraction Bingo” or “Multiplication Race”

Hands-on Manipulatives: Use physical objects to represent mathematical concepts.

Example: Using Lego bricks for addition and subtraction

Real-world Applications: Connect math to everyday situations.

Example: Planning a class party budget

Technology Integration: Use interactive apps and software.

Example: Geogebra for geometry exploration

title: Module 5: Lesson planning and assessment
text:
Organizing Standards and Lesson Activities






Effective lesson planning aligns standards with engaging activities and clear learning objectives.




Steps for Organizing a Math Lesson:

Identify the Standard:

Example: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.NF.A.1 - Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts.

Set Clear Objectives:

Example: “By the end of the lesson, students will be able to represent and explain fractions using visual models.”

Plan Engaging Activities:

Opening: Fraction scavenger hunt in the classroom
Main Activity: Creating fraction art with colored paper
Closure: Peer teaching of fraction concepts

Incorporate Multiple Representations:

Visual: Fraction circles and number lines
Kinesthetic: Folding paper to show fractions
Symbolic: Writing fractions in numeric form

Differentiation Strategies:

Provide fraction tiles for struggling students
Challenge advanced students with equivalent fractions

title: Module 5: Lesson planning and assessment
text:
Improving Assessments for Elementary Mathematics






Effective assessment in mathematics goes beyond traditional testing, especially in preparation for high-stakes exams.





Strategies for Improved Math Assessments:

Formative Assessment Techniques:

Exit tickets: Quick problem-solving at lesson’s end
Think-Pair-Share: Students discuss solutions with peers
Digital polls: Real-time feedback on concept understanding

Performance-Based Assessments:

Math projects: Design a playground using geometric shapes
Math journals: Students explain their problem-solving process

Differentiated Assessments:

Tiered assignments: Varying complexity levels
Choice boards: Students select from assessment options

Test Preparation Strategies:

Regular practice with standardized question formats
Teaching test-taking strategies (e.g., eliminating wrong answers)
Stress-reduction techniques for test anxiety

Technology-Enhanced Assessments:

Adaptive online quizzes
Virtual manipulatives in digital assessments

title: Historical STEM Figures Assignment Rubric
text:
This rubric will be used to assess your work on the Historical STEM Figure Project. It evaluates the research quality, content creation, STEM content, and educational application of your project.

Historical STEM Figure Project Rubric









Criteria
Exemplary (4)
Good (3)
Acceptable (2)
Needs Improvement (1)




Research Quality
Thorough research with diverse sources; all information is accurate and relevant to the figure’s contributions.
Adequate research with mostly accurate information; some minor gaps in relevance or depth.
Limited research; some inaccuracies or irrelevant information present.
Minimal research; significant inaccuracies and irrelevant content.


Content Creation
Highly creative and engaging format that effectively communicates the figure’s significance; excellent use of visuals/audio.
Good format that communicates the figure’s significance; some creativity but may lack engagement.
Basic format that meets requirements but lacks creativity or depth in presentation.
Poorly executed format that fails to engage; does not meet assignment requirements.


STEM Content
Comprehensive coverage of the individual’s STEM contributions; clear explanation of scientific/technological concepts; strong historical context provided.
Good coverage of STEM contributions; adequate explanation of concepts; some historical context provided.
Basic coverage of STEM contributions; limited explanation of concepts; minimal historical context.
Insufficient coverage of STEM contributions; unclear or missing explanations; lack of historical context.


Educational Application
It is clear how the content can be effectively used with elementary students; activities are age-appropriate and engaging.
Offers some good examples of content application for elementary students; activities are mostly age-appropriate.
Provides basic examples of content use; some activities may not be suitable for elementary level.
Few or no examples of how to use content with elementary students; activities are not age-appropriate.






Exemplary (4): Demonstrates exceptional understanding and execution of the criteria.
Good (3): Shows solid understanding and execution with minor areas for improvement.
Acceptable (2): Meets basic expectations but has significant areas for improvement.
Needs Improvement (1): Falls short of expectations in most areas.

Gladys West


Gladys Mae West, born on October 27, 1930, in Sutherland, Virginia, is a pioneering mathematician whose work significantly contributed to the development of the Global Positioning System (GPS). After earning her Bachelor’s degree in mathematics from Virginia State College in 1952 and a Master’s degree in 1955, she began her career at the U.S. Naval Proving Ground, where she developed mathematical models that accurately represented the Earth’s shape, essential for GPS technology.
Gladys West is often referred to as one of the “hidden figures” in the history of NASA and military technology, West’s contributions went largely unrecognized for many years. In 2018, she was inducted into the United States Air Force Hall of Fame and named one of the BBC’s 100 Women, highlighting her legacy in STEM and inspiring future generations, particularly women of color, to pursue careers in science and technology.

text:
Module Overview
This module explores fundamental concepts in mathematics, focusing on numbers and sets within the context of problem-solving strategies. It is designed for teachers of grades 4-6 in urban classrooms. The module covers the history of problem-solving in mathematics, introduces George Polya’s problem-solving approach, delves into number theory, and examines the concept of sets and various number systems. By the end of this module, you will have a comprehensive understanding of these topics and be equipped to apply problem-solving strategies in their classrooms.

title: Module 2: Numbers and sets
text:
Problem Solving
Problem-solving has been a central focus in mathematics education for decades. The emphasis on problem-solving strategies gained momentum in the 1980s, with the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM) highlighting its importance in their standards. Since then, various approaches have been developed to enhance students’ problem-solving skills, including heuristic strategies, metacognitive techniques, and collaborative problem-solving.
Who is George Polya?
George Polya (1887-1985) was a Hungarian mathematician who made significant contributions to various fields of mathematics. He is best known for his work on problem-solving, particularly his book “How to Solve It” (1945), which outlines a systematic approach to problem-solving.
Polya’s problem-solving approach consists of four main steps:

Understand the problem: This step involves carefully reading the problem, identifying key information, and clarifying any unfamiliar terms or concepts.
Devise a plan: Here, the problem-solver considers various strategies and selects an appropriate approach. This may include drawing diagrams, looking for patterns, or working backwards.
Carry out the plan: In this step, the chosen strategy is implemented, and calculations are performed. It’s important to check each step for accuracy[2].
Look back: After obtaining a solution, the problem-solver reviews their work, verifies the result, and considers alternative methods or extensions of the problem[2].

Example 1: Solve the equation 2x + 5 = 13

Understand: We need to find the value of x that makes the equation true.
Plan: Isolate x by subtracting 5 from both sides, then divide by 2.
Execute: 2x + 5 = 13 2x = 8 x = 4
Look back: Check if 2(4) + 5 = 13, which it does.

Example 2: Find the area of a rectangle with perimeter 24 cm and length 3 cm longer than its width.

Understand: We need to find the area, given the perimeter and a relationship between length and width.
Plan: Let w be the width. Express length as w + 3. Use the perimeter formula to find w, then calculate the area.
Execute: 2(w + (w + 3)) = 24 4w + 6 = 24 4w = 18 w = 4.5 cm length = 7.5 cm Area = 4.5 × 7.5 = 33.75 cm²
Look back: Verify that the perimeter is indeed 24 cm and the length is 3 cm longer than the width.

title: Module 2: Numbers and sets
text:
History of Number Theory
Number theory has a rich history of problem-solving approaches. Some famous theorems include:

Fermat’s Last Theorem: Pierre de Fermat claimed in 1637 that no three positive integers a, b, and c can satisfy the equation a^n + b^n = c^n for any integer n > 2. This theorem was finally proved by Andrew Wiles in 1995, after centuries of attempts.
The Goldbach Conjecture: Proposed by Christian Goldbach in 1742, it states that every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes. While widely believed to be true, it remains unproven.
The Riemann Hypothesis: Proposed by Bernhard Riemann in 1859, this conjecture about the distribution of prime numbers is considered one of the most important unsolved problems in mathematics.

title: Module 2: Numbers and sets
text:
Sets
A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects. Set theory provides a foundation for much of modern mathematics. Key concepts include:

Set notation: {1, 2, 3} represents a set containing the elements 1, 2, and 3.
Subsets: A is a subset of B if every element of A is also in B.
Set operations: union (∪), intersection (∩), difference (-), complement.
Venn diagrams: Visual representations of set relationships.

title: Module 2: Numbers and sets
text:
Numbers
The sets of numbers form a hierarchy:

Natural numbers (ℕ): Positive integers used for counting.
Whole numbers (ℕ0): Natural numbers plus zero.
Integers (ℤ): Positive and negative whole numbers.
Rational numbers (ℚ): Numbers that can be expressed as fractions.
Irrational numbers: Numbers that cannot be expressed as fractions (e.g., π, √2, √3).
Real numbers (ℝ): The union of rational and irrational numbers.
Complex numbers (ℂ): Numbers with a real and imaginary part.

Natural numbers

Definition: Positive integers used for counting (1, 2, 3, …)
Also called counting numbers
Denoted by N or ℕ Smallest natural number: 1
No largest natural number (infinite set)

Whole numbers

Definition: Natural numbers plus zero (0, 1, 2, 3, …)
Includes all non-negative integers

Key differences

Natural numbers start at 1, whole numbers start at 0
Whole numbers are a superset of natural numbers

title: Module 2: Numbers and sets
text:
Teaching Sets

Introduce the concept of a set as a collection of distinct objects
Start with concrete, familiar examples (e.g., set of fruits, set of colors)

Basic Set Concepts

Teach set notation: { } for listing elements, \(\epsilon\) for “is an element of”
Explain finite and infinite sets
Introduce the empty set (∅ or { })

Set Relationships and Operations

Teach subset (⊆) and proper subset (⊂) relationships
Introduce set operations: union (∪), intersection (∩), difference (-)
Use Venn diagrams to visually represent set relationships

Progression

Begin with simple, countable sets
Move to more abstract sets (e.g., even numbers, prime numbers)
Introduce set operations and relationships
Connect sets to other mathematical concepts (e.g., number systems, probability)

Teaching Strategies

Use manipulatives for hands-on exploration of sets
Employ visual aids like Venn diagrams and Carroll diagrams
Encourage students to create their own sets and classify objects
Integrate set theory into problem-solving activities

Real-world Applications

Discuss how sets are used in databases and computer science
Explore set applications in logic and reasoning
Show how sets relate to grouping and categorization in everyday life

Common Misconceptions

Address the difference between a set and its elements
Clarify that order doesn’t matter in sets (unlike in sequences)
Explain that repeated elements are counted only once in a set

title: Module 2: Numbers and sets
text:
Teaching Numbers

Start with natural numbers (1, 2, 3, …) for counting and basic operations
Introduce whole numbers, including zero
Emphasize place value concepts and number relationships

Teaching Fractions

Begin with concrete models and visual representations
Use fraction walls and number lines to demonstrate equivalence
Introduce proper fractions before improper fractions and mixed numbers
Focus on conceptual understanding before moving to procedures

Teaching Decimals

Connect decimals to fractions, especially tenths and hundredths
Use place value language (e.g., “two-tenths and four-hundredths” for 0.24)
Employ visual models like decimal grids and number lines

Connecting Fractions and Decimals

Explicitly show the relationship between fractions and decimals
Use double number lines to compare fractions and decimals
Demonstrate conversion between fractions and decimals

Key Teaching Strategies

Use manipulatives and visual models extensively
Encourage students to make connections between concepts
Provide ample opportunities for practice and discussion
Address common misconceptions (e.g., longer decimal doesn’t always mean larger number)
Integrate real-world applications and problem-solving

Progression

Teach fractions before decimals to build a strong conceptual foundation
Introduce decimals as an extension of the place value system
Show how decimals relate to fractions, especially tenths and hundredths
Gradually increase complexity, moving to operations with fractions and decimals

History of Number Theory
Number theory has a rich history of problem-solving approaches. Some famous theorems include:

Fermat’s Last Theorem: Pierre de Fermat claimed in 1637 that no three positive integers a, b, and c can satisfy the equation a^n + b^n = c^n for any integer n > 2. This theorem was finally proved by Andrew Wiles in 1995, after centuries of attempts.
The Goldbach Conjecture: Proposed by Christian Goldbach in 1742, it states that every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes. While widely believed to be true, it remains unproven.
The Riemann Hypothesis: Proposed by Bernhard Riemann in 1859, this conjecture about the distribution of prime numbers is considered one of the most important unsolved problems in mathematics.

Sets
A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects. Set theory provides a foundation for much of modern mathematics. Key concepts include:

Set notation: {1, 2, 3} represents a set containing the elements 1, 2, and 3.
Subsets: A is a subset of B if every element of A is also in B.
Set operations: union (∪), intersection (∩), difference (-), complement.
Venn diagrams: Visual representations of set relationships.

text:
Numbers
The sets of numbers form a hierarchy:

Natural numbers (ℕ): Positive integers used for counting.
Whole numbers (ℕ0): Natural numbers plus zero.
Integers (ℤ): Positive and negative whole numbers.
Rational numbers (ℚ): Numbers that can be expressed as fractions.
Irrational numbers: Numbers that cannot be expressed as fractions (e.g., π, √2, √3).
Real numbers (ℝ): The union of rational and irrational numbers.
Complex numbers (ℂ): Numbers with a real and imaginary part.


Natural numbers

Definition: Positive integers used for counting (1, 2, 3, …)
Also called counting numbers
Denoted by N or ℕ Smallest natural number: 1
No largest natural number (infinite set)



Whole numbers

Definition: Natural numbers plus zero (0, 1, 2, 3, …)
Includes all non-negative integers


Key differences

Natural numbers start at 1, whole numbers start at 0
Whole numbers are a superset of natural numbers

text:
Logic
Logic refers to the principles of reasoning, especially correct reasoning. It’s the systematic method of coming to conclusions through rational thought. In mathematics, logic involves the formal principles of reasoning and inference used to derive valid conclusions.
Reasoning

Deductive reasoning: Deductive reasoning is a logical process that involves drawing specific conclusions from general premises or principles that are assumed to be true. This form of reasoning is often described as a “top-down” approach, where one starts with a general statement and applies it to a specific case. In mathematics, deductive reasoning involves using established rules, facts, and theorems to draw specific conclusions. It moves from general principles to specific instances.
Inductive reasoning: Inductive reasoning is a logical process that involves drawing general conclusions from specific observations or instances. This method is often referred to as “bottom-up” reasoning, contrasting with deductive reasoning, which moves from general principles to specific conclusions. In mathematics, inductive reasoning involves observing patterns or specific instances to form general conclusions or hypotheses.
Using if-then statements

Structure in mathematics refers to the way mathematical objects are organized or arranged. It involves the relationships and patterns between mathematical entities, such as the properties of number systems or the organization of geometric shapes.

Space
In mathematics, space refers to the framework within which points, lines, shapes, and other geometric objects exist. It can be two-dimensional (like a plane), three-dimensional (like our physical world), or even higher-dimensional in abstract mathematics.

title: Module 1: Logic and the language of mathematics

Change
Change in mathematics deals with how quantities or properties vary or transform over time or under different conditions. This concept is fundamental to areas like calculus, which studies rates of change and accumulation.

title: Module 1: Logic and the language of mathematics
text:
Zero
Formal Definition
Zero is a number that represents the absence of quantity or magnitude. It is the integer between the set of all negative integers and all positive integers.
Examples
The empty set: \(\emptyset\) or \(\{ \}\).
The number line: A starting point on number line.
Counting: of you have a basket of apples and remove all of the apples, you are left with zero apples.
Temperature: On the Celsius scale, zero degrees represents the freezing point of water.
Key Points:
Zero as a placeholder in our number system.
The role of zero in mathematics (e.g., additive identity).
Historical developments of the concept of zero:

Dividing a number by zero, \(\dfrac{x}{0} = \text{undefined}\) for some number \(x \neq 0\)
Dividing zero by zero, \(\dfrac{x}{0} = \text{undefined}\) for some number \(x = 0\).

title: Module 1: Logic and the language of mathematics
text:
Infinity
Formal Definition
Infinity is a concept describing something without any limit, and is larger than any real number. It is often denoted by the symbol \(\infty\).
Examples
The number line: You can always add 1 to any number, no matter how large, so the number line extends infinitely.
Fractional division: 1 divided by 3 results in a repeating decimal (0.333…) that goes on infinitely.
Key Points
Different types of infinity (countable and uncountable)
The concept of infinity in mathematics vs. everyday life
Paradoxes involving infinity (e.g., Hilbert’s Hotel)

The Common Core State Standards (CCSS) - Mathematics were adopted by the DC State Board of Education (July, 2010), as the K-12 Math Standards for the District of Columbia. Schools began a staged implementation of the standards during the 2011-12 school year. From 2011-2014, teachers received ongoing training in Common Core implementation, with full implementation occurring during the 2014-15 school year.
The CCSS-Mathematics demand a shift in math instruction from an emphasis on procedural fluency towards a balance between procedural fluency, conceptual understanding and application of concepts, so students are better prepared for the critical thinking necessary to succeed in college, careers and their daily lives. OSSE seeks to support high-quality implementation of the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics.

Course goals

This course will explore how we understand our dual identities as learners of mathematics and as teachers of mathematics (and quantification) in a society that, broadly, has had adverse experiences with mathematics.
This could will focus on how we can develop a good understanding of the principles of logical reasoning and explore how mathematical language shapes our thinking about different real-world scenarios and applications.
This course will allow us to develop our skills to analyze and construct mathematical arguments, and to connect logic to real-world teaching and learning scenarios.
This course will support your thinking about how to develop lessons and unit-plans that support the above priorities: exploring how we understand oursevles and others as mathematical people, developing a good understandign of logic and mathemtical language, and developing our skills to create lessons that construct mathematical arguments to a diverse set of scenaiors and contexts.
